did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Edward Clark proclamation contains two photocopies of an 1861 proclamation by Texas Governor Edward Clark, calling for a military force of 2,000 to be raised for service in the Confederate Army.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Edward Clark (1815-1880), governor of the state of Texas in 1861, was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. He moved to Texas in 1841 and practiced law in Marshall. As a delegate to the Texas Constitutional Convention in 1845, he helped craft the initial state constitution. He later served as a state representative and senator. During the Mexican-American War, he temporarily set aside his political career to serve as an aide to General J. Pinckney Henderson. In 1853, he served as Texas secretary of state and later served as commissioner of claims. In 1859, he was elected lieutenant governor of Texas, with Sam Houston serving as governor.

In 1861, when Sam Houston refused to take the oath of allegiance to the Confederacy, Houston was deposed as governor and Edward Clark was installed as governor. Clark worked with Confederate officials to raise troops and money to support the war effort, as well as communicating with nearby Mexico and various Native American tribes in West Texas and Indian Territory (-present day Oklahoma).

Clark was defeated by Francis R. Lubbock in the 1861 election for Texas governor. Despite allegations of fraud, Clark transitioned the governor's office to Lubbock without protest and was commissioned into the Confederate Army as a colonel. After being wounded in the Battle of Pleasant Hill in 1864, he received an honorable discharge and returned to Texas. At the end of the war, Clark spent a short time in Mexico before returning to Texas. He was active in veterans' groups and fraternal organizations until his death in 1880 May 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Edward Clark proclamation includes two photostatic copies of a broadside printed 1861 August 26 at Austin, Texas, calling upon 2,000 people to organize for military service with the Confederate States of America. There are no original materials in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Edward Clark proclamation was arranged in a single folder prior to current processing.
Currently, the Edward Clark proclamation is arranged in one series: I. Proclamations.
